title: LeBron James feeds firefighters battling Southern California blazes with his taco trucks
text:
LeBron James sent taco trucks to feed firefighters battling the wildfires in the greater Los Angeles area, after he was among the Southern California residents who had to vacate their homes amid the ongoing blazes in the Getty Fire.

'My appreciation and loyalty to the first responders,' the 34-year-old said in a news conference Tuesday prior to the Lakers home game at Staples Center. 'Those guys, men and women are unbelievable, what they're doing and their bravery throughout this time.'

The Akron, Ohio native said that firefighters and first responders are the 'the reason why things could be a lot less worse than they could be,' commending them for their bravery, commitment and sacrifice to their craft.

Looking after people: NBA superstar LeBron James, 34, sent taco trucks Tuesday to feed firefighters battling the wildfires in the greater Los Angeles area, after he was among the Southern California residents who had to vacate their homes amid the ongoing blazes in the Getty Fire

'It definitely doesn't go without noticing, without appreciation,' he added.

The Los Angeles Laker superstar was evacuated from his Brentwood home early Monday, and is staying with his family in a hotel as firefighters face off with the flames.

'Finally found a place to accommodate us! Crazy night man!' he said in a series of tweets. 'I [pray] for all the families in the area that could be affected by these [wildfires] now! Pretty please get to safety ASAP.'

The 6ft8 basketball stalwart added, 'My best wishes as well to the first responders right now doing what they do best!'

Grateful: LeBron said of the firefighters and first responders, 'Those guys, men and women are unbelievable, what they're doing and their bravery throughout this time'

Heroes: Four firefighters recharged with platters of tacos amid their difficult assignment

California-based politicians including Gov. Gavin Newsom and Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti took to Twitter to praise the NBA legend, who owned a home in the area prior to inking a four-year $154 million contract with the Lakers in July of 2018.

'Shout out to @KingJames for generously sending over a taco truck to support our LA firefighters, first responders, and law enforcement folks that have been on the front lines fighting the #GettyFire,' Newsom said.

Garcetti said, 'Thank you, @KingJames, for generously sending a taco truck to support our @LAFD firefighters, first responders, and partner agencies working to fight the #GettyFire.'

The hoops staple, who's also played for the Cleveland Cavaliers and Miami Heat, was celebrating his 16th year on the court Tuesday, which marked the anniversary of his October 29, 2003 debut.
